All these rites, necessarily accomplished apart from any ecclesiastical assembly, lack that publicity which is the ordinary and prescribed condition, for example, of baptism and ordination. If I have admitted marriage, which has rather the aspect of a family ceremony than that of an ecclesiastica] act, it is because marriage implies a publicity beyond that of the family circle, and brings together all the members of the local Christian community. The bride and bridegroom are married before the Church, and not solely in the presence of Cod and their imme- diate family and friends. It was also necessary to exclude from this work all the forms for the venera- tion of saints, relies, imageS‚ and for the benediction of houses, firstfruits, etc. It would require another volume to deal adequately with these varied mani- festations of individua] and popular piety‚ which have received the protection, and indeed the encouragement, of the Church, without having been elevated by her to the dignity of those great rites which constitute the actual procedure of the ecclesiastical authority —that is, of the Christian priesthood. There is no place in this book for the consideration of the forms employed by the individual worshipping God in private. It is concerned solely with the assembly of Christiane in the Church, and the prayers dealt With will therefore always have a collective character, in whatever measure the various members of the congregation may join in their outward expression.
